docs.lead_paragraph: More than a year ago, when President Bush chose the Houston urologist Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach, then 60, to direct the National Cancer Institute, with its $4.6 billion annual budget, politicians from all parties cheered the appointment. As the director of the genitourinary cancer division at the M.D. Anderson Cancer Center, Dr. von Eschenbach had spent his career as a clinician doing battle with men's cancers. In off-hours, he was a strong voice for increased funding for cancer research and for greater participation by patients in policy decisions. When he was chosen for the cancer institute job, Dr. von Eschenbach was president-elect of the American Cancer Society, the nation's leading cancer charity.

headline.main: Director Tries to Untangle Web of Cancer Controversies
headline.kicker: A CONVERSATION WITH ANDREW VON ESCHENBACH

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr Andrew von Eschenbach, director of National Cancer Institute, on his clinical background, his own two cancers, controversies in cancer research and posting of fact sheet on institute's Web site about potential link between abortion and breast cancer; photo (M)
docs.snippet: More than a year ago, when President Bush chose the Houston urologist Dr. Andrew von Eschenbach, then 60, to direct the National Cancer Institute, with its $4.6 billion annual budget, politicians from all parties cheered the appointment.    As the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Drugs that interfere with H.I.V. have had a major effect in reducing death and disability from AIDS. Now drug companies are beginning to test the first similar drugs for the hepatitis C virus, which can cause fatal liver disease and has infected far more people than H.I.V. ''If they work, they could have the same impact on H.C.V. that the H.I.V. drugs do,'' said Dr. Frank Chisari, a professor of virology at the Scripps Research Institute in San Diego.

headline.main: H.I.V. Lessons Used in Hepatitis C Treatment

docs.abstract: Drug companies are beginning to test drugs that interfere with enzymes that hepatitis C virus needs to replicate, like protease and polymerase; are encouraged by report from Boehringer Ingelheim, German drug company, that its experimental protease inhibitor reduced viral levels by range of hundredfold to more than a thousandsfold in small number of patients who took drug for only two days; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Drugs that interfere with H.I.V. have had a major effect in reducing death and disability from AIDS. Now drug companies are beginning to test the first similar drugs for the hepatitis C virus, which can cause fatal liver disease and has infected far...

docs.lead_paragraph: Five years after the Food and Drug Administration first approved a specially packaged formulation of birth control pills as a backup contraceptive method, experts estimate that 4 or 5 percent of women ages 18 to 44 have used the emergency contraception. Birth control advocates say the usage level is low because of limited access to the pills, but they say the situation may be changing as policy makers test a variety of mechanisms to increase access to the so-called morning-after pills in doctors' offices, clinics and emergency rooms.
docs.abstract: Birth control advocates seek to make morning-after birth control pills more accessible to women; a few states have done away with requirement for individual prescriptions for emergency contraception; opponents argue that morning-after pills cause rather than prevent abortions and should not be available at all (M)
docs.snippet: Five years after the Food and Drug Administration first approved a specially packaged formulation of birth control pills as a backup contraceptive method, experts estimate that 4 or 5 percent of women ages 18 to 44 have used the emergency...

docs.lead_paragraph: Programs set up to give elementary school students tools to avoid violent behavior are showing positive results, according to two articles published yesterday. One study looked at about 11,000 New York City students who had been trained in the Resolving Conflict Creatively Program, which has been offered to about 200,000 youngsters since its creation in 1985. With it, students are taught strategies for dealing with conflict without resorting to violence.
docs.abstract: Programs set up to give elementary school students tools to avoid violent behavior show positive results in New York City and Pima County, Ariz; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Young adults who said they ate breakfast every day were almost half as likely to be obese as those who ate breakfast twice a week or less, a study presented last week at an American Heart Association conference in Miami found. Those who ate breakfast were also less likely, at the same rate, to suffer from insulin resistance syndrome, often a precursor to diabetes.
docs.abstract: Young adults who say they eat breakfast every day are found to be almost half as likely to be obese as those who say they eat breakfast twice a week or less; are also less likely, at same rate, to suffer from insulin resistance syndrome, often precursor to diabetes (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: About 5 percent of any group of Medicare patients are made ill by their medicines during treatment outside the hospital over the course of a year, and many of those illnesses can be prevented, a new study has found. Surveys show that almost half of Americans over 65 take five or more different medicines a week.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Turn Back the Clock Without Losing Time,'' by Dr. Rhoda S. Narins and Dr. Paul Jarrod Frank. Three Rivers Press, $14. Not so long ago, cosmetic surgery was primarily invasive, a sometimes painful experience reserved for the socially elite and requiring a long hospital stay and weeks of seclusion.
docs.abstract: John Langone reviews Turn Back the Clock Without Losing Time, guide to quick and easy cosmetic procedures by Dr Rhoda S Narins and Dr Paul Jarrod Frank (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The phrase ''it can't be done'' does not seem to be a part of the vocabulary of Dr. Janice E. Brunstrom. Born 40 years ago, she was three months premature and weighed just three pounds. She has cerebral palsy that cripples both legs. Her parents were told she would be mentally retarded, a prospect that seemed highly unlikely when she learned to read at 4 and was further refuted when she became her high school's valedictorian.

headline.main: Living With Cerebral Palsy, in the Gym and With a Kick

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on cerebral palsy, its causes and varying levels of disability that come under diagnosis; describes comprehensive treatment offered at St Louis Children's Hospital under program established by Dr Janice E Brunstrom, who has cerebral palsy that crippled both legs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: What's at stake in a name? When it comes to prescription drugs, sometimes your physical or mental health. Just ask my patient Lisa. For nearly half of her 40 years, Lisa struggled with bipolar disorder and had finally been stabilized on a number of medications, including the mood-stabilizing anticonvulsant Lamictal. Two weeks after a routine office visit, she called complaining of irritability and insomnia, early warning signs of a relapse.

headline.main: Do Spelling and Penmanship Count? In Medicine, You Bet

docs.abstract: Dr Richard A Friedman article on potentially lethal prescription errors that are made because certain drugs either sound alike or have similar spelling; says problem that is aggravated by fact that many prescriptions are phoned in to pharmacist or written in a doctor's notoriously bad handwriting (M)
docs.snippet: What's at stake in a name? When it comes to prescription drugs, sometimes your physical or mental health. Just ask my patient Lisa.    For nearly half of her 40 years, Lisa struggled with bipolar disorder and had finally been stabilized on a number...

docs.lead_paragraph: To a car lover, seeing a familiar car can feel a lot like seeing a familiar face. In fact, according to a study released online yesterday, the neural connection that creates a sense of instant recognition can also make it harder for the car buff to recognize a familiar car and a familiar person at the same time. In recognizing most objects, the brain pieces together different bits of the visual image together before deciding what it is, but familiar faces are recognized through ''holistic perception,'' that is, taken in at a glance as a single object.

headline.main: Inside the Brain of a Car Lover

docs.abstract: Study with car buffs suggests that same neural pathways that are used to recognize faces are used to recognize other familiar objects; cartoon (M)
